intro: Centropogon mellitus var. peruvianus, commonly known as the Peruvian trumpet flower, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive, tubular, brightly colored flowers that resemble trumpets. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a velvety texture, while its flowers bloom in clusters, attracting various pollinators. This variant is noted for its ornamental value and is occasionally cultivated in gardens for its striking appearance.
